newsitem.title: NIGERIA: Nigeria oil firms warn new rules may raise costs.
newsitem.headline: Nigeria oil firms warn new rules may raise costs.

text.p: Nigeria's joint venture oil operators on Friday warned that new government orders on cash contributions could result in another layer of bureaucracy and increased oil production costs.

"The most worrying thing is the question of handling the money, and the possibility of more government interference, which has to be interpreted as more bureaucratic tangles," one joint venture oil company official said.

Late on Thursday oil minister Dan Etete told oil executives that Nigeria was not getting a fair deal from the oil joint ventures and set out a new way for government contributions for production and exploration be paid, among other measures.

"We already have extensive vetting, with strict contract approvals and again for cash-calls, there is no need for any more. It would inevitably increase costs, and probably the delay in cash-call payments. It would hurt the joint ventures, in which Nigeria has the largest share," the company official said.
"We are still trying to work out what it really means. It may be a matter of rhetoric, or it may be that the minister has definite plans worked out," another company official said.

Delays in cash-call payments have frequently provoked the ire of the oil companies in the past, and this year government has cut by 30 percent its initial budget provision of $2 billion for oil operations, a decision challenged by the companies.
Ongoing negotiations between the two sides are trying to hammer out new Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) rules for joint venture operations.

Analysts say budget cuts make it unlikely that Nigeria will reach its turn of the century output capacity target of 2.5 million barrels a day. The government is under severe pressure from a $32 billion foreign debt to keep spending under control.
State-run Nigerian National Petroleum Corp (NNPC) is the majority partner in joint ventures with subsidiaries of Royal Dutch/Shell Group, Mobil Corp, Chevron Corp, Agip SpA and Elf Aquitaine.
Nigeria pumps around two million barrels of crude a day.
